questions.question: What is the interpretation of the following PTA conducted on a patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mixed hearing loss Explanation: Both air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) are defective. However, AC and BC are not equally defective, as there is a significant air-bone gap (>15 dB). This confirms the presence of mixed hearing loss. Pure Tone Audiometry: AC & BC are tested with the help of pure tones produced by Audiometer Charted in a graph called Audiogram It is a subjective test that relies on patient feedback to determine hearing thresholds across various frequencies. AC vs. BC (A-B Gap): Indicates the degree of conductive deafness. Aspect Air Conduction (AC) Bone Conduction (BC) Frequency Range 125 - 8000 Hz 250 - 4000 Hz Indicates Overall hearing sensitivity Cochlear function Normal Ear Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies) No significant A-B gap Conductive Hearing Loss AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal. BC Thresholds: Within normal limits. A-B Gap (>20db): Significant Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) AC Thresholds: Elevated BC Thresholds: Elevated to

questions.question: Carhart's notch is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Otosclerosis Explanation: Carhart’s notch is a characteristic dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz seen in otosclerosis. It is an audiometric finding caused by stapes fixation, which affects the transmission of sound through the ossicular chain. Feature Otosclerosis Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) Air Conduction Loss, more pronounced at lower frequencies - Bone Conduction and Characteristic pattern Normal, may show "Carhart's notch" at 2000 Hz (5-15 dB loss) Typical notch at 4000 Hz in both air and bone conduction (Boiler's notch) Hearing Loss Mixed Sensorineural Ossicular Discontinuity (Option B): This typically presents with conductive hearing loss but does not show Carhart’s notch. Oto Syphilis (Option C): This can cause sensorineural hearing loss due to cochlear involvement but does not present with Carhart’s notch. Serous Otitis Media (Option D): This results in conductive hearing loss due to fluid in the middle ear, but it does not cause the characteristic Carhart’s notch.

questions.question: Which one of the following causes maximum hearing loss:

options.B: Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane
options.C: Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane Explanation: Among the given options, ossicular discontinuity with an intact tympanic membrane leads to the highest hearing loss, around 55 dB. Hearing Loss Degrees in Different Conditions: Tympanic Membrane (TM) perforation → 10–40 dB hearing loss Complete obstruction of External Auditory Canal (EAC) → 30–40 dB hearing loss TM perforation with ossicular discontinuity → 40 dB hearing loss Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM → 55 dB hearing loss Complete fixation of the footplate of the stapes (seen in otosclerosis) → 60 dB hearing loss Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5023437/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5023437/

questions.question: Most common hearing test done in neonates for screening:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) OAE Explanation: OAE is the preferred screening test in neonates due to its ease of use, reliability, and non-invasiveness. Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) : is a test in which emissions are generated by outer hair cells and are used to evaluate hearing in individuals with cognitive impairments. OAEs are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal. Pathway: The absence of OAE indicates damage in the outer hair cell (conditions like lesions of the cochlea, middle ear disorders, etc.). Types: Spontaneous OAEs involve emissions without any external stimulation (sound). They may be absent in 50% of the individuals. Evoked OAEs require an external stimulus. Transient evoked OAEs (TEOAEs) : Evoked by clicks (mixture of various frequencies). Distortion product OAEs: Two tones (specific frequencies) are simultaneously presented to the cochlea to produce distortion products. Uses of OAE: They are used as a screening test for neonates, uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals. Differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss. Helpful in early detection of noise-induced hearing loss. Clap & Smile (Option A): This is an informal behavioral response test that is subjective and unreliable for neonatal hearing screening. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) (Option B): This is used for diagnostic confirmation in high-risk infants (ICU) but is not the first-line screening test due to its higher cost and complexity. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) (Option D): This requires active patient participation, which is not possible in neonates.

questions.question: Which procedure is shown in the following diagram?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stapedotomy Explanation: The image depicts stapedotomy, a surgical procedure used to treat otosclerosis. Procedure: A small hole is created in the stapes footplate, and a prosthesis is placed to restore the transmission of sound vibrations to the inner ear. This procedure helps improve conductive hearing loss caused by stapes fixation. Stapedotomy vs. Stapedectomy Procedure Description Complications Stapedotomy A small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted. Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists. Stapedectomy Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device. Higher risk of complications. Myringotomy (Option B): This involves creating a small incision in the tympanic membrane to drain middle ear fluid, commonly used in otitis media with effusion. Myringoplasty (Option C): This is a surgical repair of a small tympanic membrane perforation, without involving the ossicles. Tympanoplasty (Option D): This is a more extensive procedure that repairs the tympanic membrane along with ossicular reconstruction if needed.

questions.question: A 49-year-old female from Nagaland presented with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, dull tympanic membrane with lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck was seen. Which of the following is the management for the condition?
questions.explanation: triangle lymphadenopathy —raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) , especially considering the geographic location (Nagaland, Northeast India, where NPC is more prevalent due to genetic and environmental factors, including Epstein-Barr virus association). Radiotherapy is the primary treatment for NPC , as it is highly radiosensitive. Other Options: Grommet insertion + Steroids (Option A) : Used for chronic OME but does not treat the underlying malignancy. Grommet insertion (Option B) : Temporary relief but inappropriate for NPC. Steroids alone (Option C) : May reduce inflammation but will not address the tumor. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 766

questions.question: A 9-month-old baby was admitted in the ICU with history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media by staph aureus. Laboratory examination showed decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, and plasma B cells. Which of the following is the condition is described here?
questions.explanation: of a 9-month-old with recurrent bacterial infections (sinusitis, otitis media) due to Staph aureus , low serum immunoglobulin levels, and absence of plasma B cells is characteristic of Bruton Syndrome (X-linked agammaglobulinemia). Bruton Syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder caused by mutations in the BTK (Bruton tyrosine kinase) gene . This results in a failure of B-cell maturation , leading to a deficiency of mature B cells and, consequently, low levels of all immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM, and IgE) in the serum. Features: Recurrent bacterial infections – especially with encapsulated organisms like Staphylococcus aureus , Streptococcus pneumoniae , and Haemophilus influenzae . Sinopulmonary infections – recurrent sinusitis and otitis media are common. Absence of mature B cells in peripheral blood – leading to a lack of plasma cells, which are responsible for antibody production. Onset after maternal antibody wanes – Symptoms usually appear around 6 months of age , when the maternal IgG (passed through the placenta) is depleted. Low levels of IgA, IgG, IgM, and IgE – due to defective B-cell development. Incorrect options: Ataxia Telangiectasia (Option A): Presents with ataxia, telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency (especially IgA deficiency), but it does not cause a complete absence of B cells and all immunoglobulins. Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) (Option B): Causes recurrent infections, but it is due to a defect in neutrophil function (NADPH oxidase deficiency) rather than low immunoglobulin levels. DiGeorge Syndrome (Option D): Caused by 22q11.2 deletion , leading to thymic hypoplasia and T-cell deficiency rather than B-cell deficiency. It is more associated with viral and fungal infections rather than recurrent bacterial infections like in Bruton Syndrome. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448170/

questions.question: A patient presents to the OPD with hearing loss. On examination: Rinne test- Positive in the left ear and negative in the right ear Weber's test - lateralization towards the left Bone conduction test - Reduced in the right ear and similar in the left ear. Interpret the findings.

options.A: Sensorineural hearing loss in left ear
options.B: Sensorineural hearing loss in right ear
options.C: Conductive hearing loss in left ear
options.D: Conductive hearing loss in right ear.

questions.explanation: sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and conductive hearing loss (CHL) . Interpretation of the tests: Test Conductive Loss Sensorineural Loss Normal Hearing Rinne Negative (BC > AC) Positive (AC > BC) Positive (AC > BC) Weber Lateralises to worse ear Lateralises to better ear Heard equally Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Hears as long as the examiner Hears for a shorter duration Hears as long as the examiner Schwabach Lengthened Reduced Normal Rinne Test: Positive in the left ear → Air conduction (AC) > Bone conduction (BC) → Normal or SNHL in the left ear. Negative in the right ear → Bone conduction > Air conduction → Conductive hearing loss (CHL) in the right ear OR a false negative due to profound SNHL . Weber Test: Lateralization to the left ear → This suggests: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear OR Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear (since Weber lateralizes to the better ear in SNHL). Bone Conduction Test: Reduced in right ear → Suggests sensorineural involvement in the right ear. Similar in left ear → No significant sensorineural loss in the left ear. Final Conclusion: Since bone conduction is reduced in the right ear , it indicates sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the right ear . Weber lateralizing to the left ear further supports SNHL in the right ear (since in SNHL, Weber localizes to the better-hearing ear). Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 234

questions.question: A patient with CSOM was presented to the OPD with seizures. On examination and evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and epilepsy were present. Identify the condition with the CT scan given below?
questions.explanation: hemianopia, and epilepsy , and the CT finding (ring-enhancing lesion), is suggestive of a temporal lobe abscess is a known complication of CSOM due to the direct spread of infection via: Tegmen tympani dehiscence (erosion of the thin bony plate between the middle ear and the brain). Hematogenous spread . Seizures and epilepsy occur due to cortical irritation from the abscess. Homonymous hemianopia suggests involvement of the optic radiations , which pass through the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) . Other Options: Cerebellar abscess (Option B): More commonly presents with ataxia, nystagmus, and vertigo , not homonymous hemianopia. Extradural abscess (Option C): Causes localized pain, fever, and sinus tenderness , but does not typically lead to seizures or hemianopia. Meningitis (Option D) : Presents with fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status , but does not usually cause focal neurological deficits like homonymous hemianopia .

questions.question: Identify the sign given in the image below:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Double target sign Explanation: The Double Ring Sign , also called the Halo Sign , is a bedside test used to detect CSF leakage in cases of CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea (leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the nose or ear). When a fluid sample (suspected to be mixed with CSF) is placed on a filter paper or gauze , it forms: An inner dark red ring (blood) An outer clear ring (CSF) This occurs because CSF is less dense and spreads outward , forming a halo or double ring pattern around the blood. Investigations for CSF Rhinorrhea Handkerchief test (Halo sign) (Option C): Simple bedside test; CSF forms clear halo around blood spot. Beta-2 transferrin (Option A): Gold standard biochemical test; highly specific for CSF. High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Identifies bony defects in skull base. CT Cisternography: Contrast-enhanced; precise localization of active CSF leaks. MRI Cisternography: Non-invasive; useful for identifying meningoceles/encephaloceles. Fluorescein Test: Intrathecal dye injection; helps in intraoperative leak localization. Other Options: The Teardrop Sign (Option D): on imaging refers to a triangular-shaped soft tissue mass often seen in orbital trauma or orbital floor fractures , indicating herniation of orbital contents. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 567

questions.question: Identify the treatment option with the image given below:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Type 3 tympanoplasty Explanation: Type 3 Tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus and incus are absent , but the stapes footplate is intact and mobile . The tympanic membrane or graft is placed directly over the stapes head to allow sound conduction. This technique helps improve hearing in cases of ossicular erosion due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), cholesteatoma, or trauma . Types of Tympanoplasty (Wullstein's Classification): Type Description Type I Defect: perforated tympanic membrane. Repaired using a graft. (myringoplasty) (Option A ruled out) Type II Defect: Eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane. Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus. (Option B ruled out) Type III Defect: Absence of malleus and incus. Graft placed directly on stapes head (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty). Type IV Defect: Only the footplate of the stapes is present. It is exposed to the external ear. A graft is placed between oval and round windows, allowing sound to act directly on the footplate and the round window is shielded. (Option D ruled out) Type V Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with right vestibular neuronitis. What findings are expected during the head impulse test in this patient?

options.A: When the head is turned to the left, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.
options.B: When the head is turned to the left, the eyeballs move to the right with nystagmus.
options.C: When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.
options.D: When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the right with nystagmus.

questions.explanation: nystagmus. (VOR), which stabilizes gaze during head movement. In a patient with right vestibular neuronitis, the right vestibular nerve is impaired. When the head is turned to the right: The right vestibular system fails to generate the appropriate signal to maintain gaze. The eyes initially move with the head to the right (which is abnormal) and then perform a quick corrective movement (catch-up saccade) to the left to refocus on the target. Incorrect Options: Options A, B and D are incorrect, as explained above. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient presents with a history of ear discharge. On examination, a small perforation is observed in the antero-inferior segment of the tympanic membrane. What is the most likely result of Rinne’s test?
questions.explanation: suggests a conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, bone conduction (BC) is better than air conduction (AC), which impedes sound waves from reaching the inner ear through air conduction. Thus, the Rinne test will be negative (BC > AC). Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.question: Match the following: 1 Greater auricular nerve 2 Auriculotemporal nerve 3 Auricular branch of the vagus nerve 4 Lesser occipital nerve
questions.explanation: auriculotemporal nerve. The area marked as B is supplied by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve. The area marked as C is supplied by the greater auricular nerve. The area marked as D is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve.

questions.question: A female patient’s Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) findings reveal a Carhart's notch. Which of the following is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation: otosclerosis, characterized by a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. Schwartz's sign is associated with otosclerosis, particularly in the active phase. This sign refers to a flamingo pink hue seen through the tympanic membrane due to increased vascularity of the mucoperiosteum overlying the otosclerotic focus. Incorrect Options: Options B, C and D are not seen in otosclerosis. Reference: .

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with a gradually progressive hearing loss in her right ear, accompanied by pulsatile tinnitus. On otoscopic examination, a red vascular mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: mass seen on otoscopy. It originates from the paraganglionic cells and is known for causing pulsatile tinnitus, as well as conductive hearing loss. The given image shows Phelp sign, which further confirms the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D do not exhibit Phelp sign. Reference: .

questions.question: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: of a 30-year-old female shown above which is called as Carhatz notch. Carhatz notch is seen in otosclerosis. The air conduction seen in the graph is also affected Incorrect Options : Meniers disease (Option B): Upsloping graph seen in Meniere's disease Both AC and BC are affected because of SNHL but the loss is seen at lower frequencies and at higher frequency the hearing sensitivity is almost normal. Low frequency type of hearing loss is a Characteristic of Meniere's disease. Noise-induced hearing loss (Option C): The BC and AC curve of the ears is in the abnormal range, which means there is sensorineural hearing loss. At 4000 Hz there is a dip in both AC and BC, this is called the boiler's notch which is specific in noise-induced hearing loss . Presbycusis (Option D): Presbyacusis is an age related SNHL. AC and BC are abnormal, with no A-B gap. This is a typical scene in sensorineural hearing loss A down-sloping graph is very specific in presbycusis Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 79

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.explanation: along with the given audiogram findings point to Meniere’s disease. In Meniere’s disease , low-frequency hearing is typically affected first. This is due to the involvement of the apical turn of the cochlea , which is responsible for detecting lower frequencies. Early stages of the disease often present with a rising audiogram pattern , with hearing loss predominantly affecting lower frequencies . As the disease progresses, higher frequencies may also become involved, leading to a more complex audiometric profile. Audiometry Findings: Sensorineural hearing loss (No AB Gap) initially affecting lower frequencies and can also involve higher frequencies in later stages. Upsloping Type The curve becomes flat/falling type in later stages once higher frequencies get affected. Incorrect Options: BPPV (Option A): In BPPV, there is no hearing loss and that is helpful in eliminating the question Vestibular neuronitis (Option C): Hearing loss is not a feature of vestibular neuronitis Presbycusis (Option D): Presbycusis is an age related SNHL. AC and BC are abnormal, with no A-B gap. This is a typical scene in sensorineural hearing loss A down-sloping graph is very specific in presbycusis

questions.question: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image?

options.A: Derived from ectoderm of 1st and 2nd arch
options.B: Derived from the pouch of 1st and 2nd arch
options.C: Derived from mesoderm of 1st and 2nd arch
options.D: Derived from ectoderm of 3rd and 4th arch

questions.explanation: also known as a preauricular sinus or fistula, is a congenital malformation resulting from incomplete or abnormal fusion of the first and second pharyngeal (branchial) arches. These structures are primarily derived from the ectoderm. The ectoderm forms the surface epithelium and contributes to the formation of various structures, including the external ear and its associated anomalies. Incorrect Options: Derived from the pouch of 1st and 2nd arch (Option B): This statement is incorrect because the periauricular sinus is not derived from the pharyngeal pouches but rather from the ectodermal layer of the arches. The pouches are internal structures that give rise to different anatomical features such as the middle ear cavity and the thymus. Derived from mesoderm of 1st and 2nd arch (Option C): The periauricular sinus is not derived from the mesoderm. Although the mesoderm contributes to muscle and connective tissue formation in the pharyngeal arches, the periauricular sinus specifically originates from the ectoderm. Derived from ectoderm of 3rd and 4th arch (Option B): This statement is incorrect because the periauricular sinus arises from the first and second pharyngeal arches, not the third and fourth. The third and fourth arches give rise to other structures such as parts of the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 34

questions.question: A diabetic patient with ear pain and an HBA1c of 10 presents with excruciating ear pain and blood-stained ear discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: which bleeds on touch, seen especially in diabetics and patients with uncontrolled HBA1c Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis Externa (MOE) Inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas infection. Commonly affects elderly diabetic patients or those on immunosuppressive therapy. Severe ear pain, granulations in the ear canal, and facial paralysis are common symptoms. Infection can spread to the skull base, jugular foramen, and cause multiple cranial nerve palsies. Etiopathogenesis: Early presentation mimics diffuse otitis externa but with intense pain. Granulations in the ear canal indicate disease progression. Infection can extend: Anteriorly to the temporomandibular fossa. Posteriorly to the mastoid. Medially into the middle ear and petrous bone. Investigations: Clinical suspicion based on severe otalgia and granulation tissue in elderly diabetics. Imaging: CT scan/MRI : Shows bone destruction and soft tissue involvement. Gallium-67 scan : Indicates soft tissue infection; useful for diagnosis and follow-up. Technetium-99 bone scan : Detects bone infection but not useful for disease monitoring due to prolonged positivity. Treatment: Control of diabetes : Essential for management. Ear canal toilet : Clean the ear, remove discharge, debris, and granulations. Antibiotics : IV Gentamicin with Ticarcillin (both ototoxic/nephrotoxic). Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime ), combined with an aminoglycoside. Quinolones (e.g., Ciprofloxacin 750 mg orally) can be combined with Rifampin . Antibiotic therapy typically lasts 6-8 weeks or longer. Culture and sensitivity of ear discharge to adjust antibiotics if non-responsive to treatment. Prolonged antibiotic treatment has largely replaced the need for radical surgery. Incorrect Options: Otitis externa (Option A): It is characterized by pain during jaw movement and can be seen in diabetics but not associated with any blood stained- ear discharge Serous otitis media (Option C): Excrutuiation pain and blood stained ear discharge are not features of serous otitis media Otomycosis (Option D): It is caused by Aspergillus niger/ Candida species in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressant persons and most often in immunocompromised people. It is characterized by white-ish discharge with black spores (Wet newspaper-like appearance) and the main symptom as itching in the external auditory canal. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 279

questions.question: A middle-aged man came to the OPD with complaints of pain and hearing loss after trauma to the right ear. Examination revealed the presence of blood clots along with irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane. The next step in management is?

options.A: Aspirate the clot and perform audiometric tests
options.C: Maintain dry ear with systemic analgesics

questions.explanation: traumatic perforation of tympanic membrane Maintaining the ear dry without the use of any liquids or procedure will help the clot to fall off in any conditions of hearing loss, clots, or trauma to the tympanic membrane Traumatic perforation of tympanic membrane: Aspect Details Definition Tear or rupture of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) due to trauma Etiology Direct trauma (e.g., cotton bud, foreign body) Barotrauma (e.g., diving, blast injury, airplane pressure changes) Slap/blow to the ear Sudden loud noise (acoustic trauma) Symptoms Sudden ear pain Hearing loss (usually conductive) Tinnitus Bleeding or clear discharge from ear Vertigo (if inner ear involved) Signs Visible perforation on otoscopy Blood/debris in the ear canal Possible absent light reflex Investigations Otoscopy (main diagnostic tool) Tuning fork tests (Rinne/Weber for hearing loss type) Audiometry (after healing or in unclear cases) Treatment Keep ear dry (avoid water entry) Most heal spontaneously within weeks Avoid ear drops unless infection suspected Antibiotics if contaminated or signs of infection Surgical repair (myringoplasty) if not healed in 6–8 weeks Incorrect Options: Aspirate the clot and perform audiometric tests (Option A): One should not aspirate the clot because it might lead to rebleeding Syringing (Option B): Syringing should never be performed in tympanic perforation or laceration Gentamycin and levofloxacin ear drops (Option D): Antibiotic ear drops should no be given because ear dryness has to be maintained for the clot to fall off later Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 76

questions.question: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.explanation: perpendicular to the orbito-meatal line is called submento vertical view or a Towne view. Incorrect Options: Waters view (Option A): This is done in AP view which is also called as occipitomental view It helps in evaluating the maxillary sinuses Caldwell's view (Option B): This is also an AP view and helps in looking at frontal and ethmoidal sinus evaluation Hirtz view (Option D): This is a submentovertical view It helps in evaluating ethmoidal and sphenoid sinusitis Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 68

questions.question: Which of the following interventions should not be done in an 8-year-old boy with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.explanation: (tympanostomy tube) insertion is typically used for managing conductive hearing loss due to middle ear effusion or recurrent otitis media. It is not indicated for sensorineural hearing loss, which involves the inner ear or auditory nerve. Incorrect Options: Option A - Preferential sitting in the classroom: This intervention is beneficial for children with hearing loss. It helps them hear better by reducing background noise and enabling them to see the teacher's face for lip reading and visual cues. Option C - Hearing aid: Hearing aids are preferred in case of bilateral moderate or moderate to severe SNHL. Option D - Cochlear implant: Cochlear implants a re preferred in bilateral severe to profound SNHL (70-90 dB hearing loss). Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following signs is not associated with otitis media with effusion?

options.B: AD curve on tympanometry with conductive hearing loss
options.C: Adenoid hypertrophy is cause of SOM

questions.explanation: tympanometry with conductive hearing loss is the wrong statement. Type B or Flat audiogram is specific in SOM. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mostly bilateral: SOM is usually bilateral and the most common cause in adenoid hypertrophy. Option C - Adenoid hypertrophy is cause of SOM: Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause of bilateral SOM. Option D - Mostly resolves on its own: Wait and watch for 3 months is recommended as it is known to resolve spontaneously.

questions.question: What is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening?
questions.explanation: used test for newborn hearing screening. Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used to confirm hearing loss in infants and only in neonates who have failed OAE. Uses of OAE: They are used as a screening test for neonates, uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals. Differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss. Helpful in early detection of noise-induced hearing loss. Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA), and Tympanometry are not the most commonly used tests for newborn hearing screening. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 3

questions.question: A patient with a history of trauma presents with hearing loss. A High-Resolution Computed Tomography (HRCT) scan was performed. Which of the following structures is not typically visualized on HRCT?
questions.explanation: technique used to obtain detailed images of the bones and air-filled spaces within the ear . The organ of Corti is a neurosensory epithelium responsible for hearing present on the basilar membrane in scala media and it is difficult to identify it on HRCT. Incorrect Options: Options A, B & C: The cochlea, Vestibule, and Semicircular canals are bony structures and can be visualized on HRCT. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 107

questions.question: Which of the following are symptoms of Gradenigo syndrome?

options.A: Ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia
options.B: Nasal discharge, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia
options.C: Ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and headache
options.D: Retro-orbital pain, Diplopia, and hearing loss

questions.explanation: Classic triad: External rectus palsy (VIth nerve palsy). Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain (Vth nerve involvement). Persistent ear discharge. Gradenigo syndrome is a rare but serious complication of middle ear infections (specifically otitis media ). It happens when the infection spreads to the petrous part of the temporal bone . Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: These are not the correct triad of Gradenigo syndrome. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 67

questions.question: Which of the following structures is responsible for balance and hearing?
questions.explanation: responsible for hearing and balance. The vestibular system is divided into 1. Peripheral: made of membranous labyrinth (SCC, utricle, and saccule) and vestibular nerve Membranous labyrinth: It is present in the labyrinth/inner ear enclosed by the bony labyrinth. The lateral wall of the vestibule (central chamber) of the bony labyrinth has the oval window (Option C) The medial wall has two recesses , A spherical recess that carries the saccule (Option A) An elliptical recess that carries the utricle The opening of the aqueduct of the vestibule is located below the elliptical recess which has the endolymphatic duct. The posterosuperior part of the vestibule has 5 openings of semicircular canals (Option B) . Vestibular nerve: Central processes of the vestibular or Scarpa’s ganglion forms the vestibular nerve. Transmits the signals from hair cells in the inner ear to the vestibular nuclei 2. Central: made of the nuclei (superior, medial, lateral, descending nuclei) and fiber tracts in CNS. Incorrect Options: Option A - Semicircular canal: The semicircular canals are responsible for maintaining balance. Option B - Cochlea: The cochlea is responsible for hearing. Option D - Organ of Corti: The organ of Corti is a sense organ of hearing located on the basilar membrane in scala media. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 345

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss that has been worsening over the past few years. Audiometry confirms conductive hearing loss, and a diagnosis of otosclerosis is made. What is the surgical treatment of choice for her condition?

options.A: Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis

questions.explanation: with the placement of a prosthesis is the surgical treatment of choice for Otosclerosis Stapedotomy vs. Stapedectomy Procedure Description Complications Stapedotomy Small opening made in the stapes footplate; a prosthesis is inserted. Lower complication rates; preferred by many otologists. Stapedectomy Complete removal of the stapes bone; replaced with a prosthetic device. Higher risk of complications. Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: Stapedotomy, Stapes mobilization, and Lemperts Fenestration operation are the surgical management of Otosclerosis, but the treatment of choice is Stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 73

questions.question: Which of the following structures contain Ostmann fat pad?
questions.explanation: contains the Ostmann pad of fat. Purpose: closure of the Eustachian tube and protection from nasopharyngeal secretions Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D do not contain the Ostmann pad of fat. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 104

questions.question: A pregnant woman with deafness presents for evaluation and is diagnosed with 50dB hearing loss. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this hearing loss?

options.A: Ossicular fixation with an intact tympanic membrane
options.B: Ossicular fixation with a damaged tympanic membrane

questions.explanation: symptoms are suggestive of otosclerosis. It occurs as ossicular fixation with an intact tympanic membrane. Pure-tone Audiometry in otosclerosis Diagnoses and characterizes hearing loss. Initial low-frequency conductive loss progresses to flat maximal loss as stapes become fixed. Carhart effect may reduce bone conduction thresholds, noticeable at 2 kHz. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not responsible for the patient’s presentation. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 35

questions.question: Identify the accurate sequence of the auditory pathway. → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Cochlear nuclei → lateral lemniscus → superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Cochlear nuclei → Superior olivary nucleus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → Cochlear nuclei → lateral lemniscus
questions.explanation: → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex Explanation: The correct auditory pathway sequence is: Eight nerve → cochlear nuclei → superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate body → auditory cortex Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 132

questions.question: A 64-year-old female patient is brought to the ENT OPD with difficulties in comprehension. On examination, her fluency is found to be intact with poor comprehension and repetition. Her Pure tone audiometry and ABR is normal. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Wernicke’s aphasia. Wernicke's aphasia is a condition where language comprehension is impaired, but speech may still have a normal rate, rhythm, and grammar. The most common cause of this type of aphasia is an ischemic stroke that affects the posterior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Pure tone audiometry and auditory brainstem response (ABR) tests are normal in this patient, indicating that there is no hearing loss or problem with the transmission of sound signals from the ear to the brain. Incorrect Options: Malingering (Option A): Malingering refers to the deliberate feigning or exaggeration of symptoms for secondary gain, which is unlikely to be in this case. Auditory cortex lesion (Option B): Auditory cortex lesions could potentially cause speech difficulties, but they would likely present with additional auditory deficits,and therefore show abnormal ABR. . Broca's aphasia (Option C): Broca's aphasia is a type of non-fluent aphasia that causes a significant reduction in the ability to produce speech spontaneously. This type of aphasia also results in a loss of normal grammatical structure, specifically in the use of small linking words like conjunctions (such as "and," "or," and "but") and prepositions. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 90

questions.question: In a 2-year-old child with a sudden onset of noisy breathing, which type of stridor is most likely to be represented by the image below?
questions.explanation: noisy breathing and an omega-shaped epiglottis (which is a common presentation of laryngomalacia), inspiratory stridor is the most likely option. Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition characterized by the softening of the tissues of the larynx above the vocal cords. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants. The epiglottis in laryngomalacia often has an elongated, curled appearance, resembling the Greek letter omega ( Ω ), which can be observed during laryngoscopy. This condition typically presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens with feeding, crying, or lying supine, and usually improves by the age of 18 to 24 months as the cartilage stiffens and the airway grows. (Option B) Expiratory: Expiratory stridor occurs when there is narrowing or obstruction of the airway during exhalation. This is less likely to be the case in a child with an omega-shaped epiglottis, as the obstruction is primarily during inspiration due to the swollen epiglottis. (Option C) Biphasic: Biphasic stridor involves noisy breathing during both inspiration and expiration. This is less likely in the given scenario, as the omega-shaped epiglottis suggests a specific structural issue related to inspiration, rather than both phases of breathing. (Option D) None of these: Given the information provided about the sudden onset of noisy breathing and the specific appearance of the epiglottis, inspiratory stridor is the most suitable choice among the options. Reference: ..

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient with chronic sinusitis and nasal congestion, which anatomical structure is the most likely drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis?
questions.explanation: bulla ethmoidalis. The bulla ethmoidalis is a rounded bony prominence in the ethmoidal labyrinth (a part of the ethmoid bone) located in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It is associated with the middle nasal concha. The middle meatus is a space located between the middle and inferior nasal conchae (turbinates), which are bony structures in the nasal cavity that help to create turbulence in the inspired air. The bulla ethmoidalis drains into the middle meatus through the ethmoid infundibulum, which is a narrow passage connecting the bulla to the middle meatus. This drainage pathway is important for proper ventilation and drainage of the frontal and anterior ethmoid sinuses. Incorrect Options: Option B - Superior meatus: The superior meatus is not the correct drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis. The superior meatus is located above the middle nasal concha and is primarily associated with the posterior ethmoid air cells. Option C - Inferior meatus: The inferior meatus is not the correct drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis. The inferior meatus is located below the middle nasal concha and is primarily associated with the nasolacrimal duct and the opening of the maxillary sinus. Option D - Middle concha: The term "middle concha" is not commonly used. Instead, there are the "superior nasal concha" and the "middle nasal concha." The middle nasal concha is located between the superior and inferior nasal conchae and contributes to the formation of the middle meatus. However, the drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis is not directly associated with the middle concha but rather with the middle meatus. Reference: .

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presenting with autophony, bilateral limb weakness and normal tympanic membrane that move with respiration. What is the probable cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: hearing one's own voice loudly), a normal tympanic membrane that moves with respiration (indicating patulous Eustachian tube), and bilateral limb weakness, are indicative of significant weight loss. Weight loss can lead to decreased fatty tissue around the Eustachian tube, causing it to remain open (patulous Eustachian tube). This condition causes the tympanic membrane to move with respiration and results in autophony. Incorrect Options: Option A - Meningioma: Meningiomas are usually slow-growing tumors that originate from the meninges, the protective layers covering the brain and spinal cord. They can cause various neurological symptoms depending on their location. While they might lead to symptoms like headache, seizures, or focal neurological deficits, they are less likely to cause the combination of symptoms described in the question, such as autophony (hearing one's own voice abnormally loud), bilateral limb weakness, and normal tympanic membrane movement with respiration. Option B - Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system, causing a wide range of neurological symptoms. These can include muscle weakness, vision problems, coordination difficulties, and sensory abnormalities. While MS can cause limb weakness, it is less likely to directly lead to symptoms like autophony or affect the movement of the tympanic membrane. Option D - Wegener’s Granulomatosis: Also known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), Wegener’s granulomatosis is a rare autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the respiratory tract and kidneys. While it can cause a range of symptoms including sinus problems, lung issues, and kidney problems, it is less likely to cause the specific combination of symptoms described in the question. Reference: ..

questions.question: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaints of vertigo which is sudden in onset, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea, vomiting and vagal symptoms. Investigations show there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation: the patient presents with the classic triad: episodic vertigo , sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and tinnitus (ringing or roaring sound in the ear) Meniere’s disease/Endolymphatic hydrops : An inner ear disorder is characterised by the excessive buildup of endolymph fluid. Age/Sex: Typically affects individuals aged 35-60, with a higher prevalence in males. Cardinal Symptoms : Vertigo Episodic with sudden onset Attacks occur in clusters, interspersed with periods of remission accompanied by nausea, vomiting, ataxia & nystagmus. Loud noises might trigger vertigo due to the Tullio phenomenon. Hearing Loss Fluctuating hearing loss may improve between attacks but may progressively worsen over time, with some degree of permanent hearing loss. Sensorineural hearing loss initially affecting lower frequencies . Patients might experience distorted hearing or Diplacusis Tinnitus Low-pitched & Roaring type It can be aggravated during acute attacks and might persist during periods of remission Aural Fullness Fluctuates & may vary in intensity Emotional Impact The recurrent nature of symptoms can lead to emotional stress and apprehension about future attacks, contributing to overall distress. Incorrect Options: Presbycusis (Option B): Age-related bilateral SNHL, mainly affecting high frequencies, with no vertigo or episodic nature. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (Option C): Characterized by brief vertigo episodes triggered by head movements, without hearing loss or tinnitus. Acoustic Neuroma (Option D): Acoustic neuromas are noncancerous, usually slow-growing tumors that form along the branches of the eighth cranial nerve (also called the vestibulocochlear nerve) Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 119

questions.question: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. He is diagnosed with otosclerosis and recommended stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests on this patient?

options.A: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear
options.B: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear
options.C: Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear
options.D: Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear

questions.explanation: patient is experiencing bilateral hearing loss, worse in the right ear due to bilateral otosclerosis. In patients with otosclerosis, there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative. Weber will be lateralized to the diseased side, meaning towards the right ear. Tests for Diagnosing Stapedial Otosclerosis Otoscopy Examines external and middle ear. Identifies abnormalities; typically, the tympanic membrane appears normal in otosclerosis. Fistula Test Evaluates inner ear response to pressure changes. Helps diagnose conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, especially with vertigo. Tuning Fork Tests Weber and Rinne's tests differentiate conductive from sensorineural hearing loss. Less sensitive than audiometry but useful when other findings are inconclusive. Audiometry Pure-tone Audiometry Diagnoses and characterizes hearing loss. Initial low-frequency conductive loss progresses to flat maximal loss as stapes become fixed. Carhart effect may reduce bone conduction thresholds, noticeable at 2 kHz. Speech Audiometry Assesses speech understanding High speech recognition with appropriate hearing aids. Stapedial Reflex Testing Assesses stapedius muscle response to sound. Reflex is often absent or abnormal in otosclerosis. Tympanometry Measures tympanic membrane and middle ear system mobility. Mobility is usually normal, but compliance may be low. Helps exclude other middle ear conditions. Imaging High-Resolution CT Scan Sensitive and specific for active otosclerosis. Reveals hypodense lesions in active disease. Less effective for inactive disease due to dense otic capsule. Incorrect Options: Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear (Option A): In otosclerosis there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative. Rinne’s Test - positive; Weber’s Test - lateralized to right ear (Option B): In otosclerosis there is a conductive type of hearing loss hence Rinne will be negative. Rinne’s Test - negative; Weber’s Test - lateralized to left ear (Option C): Weber will be lateralized to the diseased side meaning towards the right ear.

questions.question: A patient presents to the OPD with the complaint of hearing loss and can understand only shouting or amplified speech. What will be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech?
questions.explanation: the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech would be severe. Normal conversation is up to 60dB Shouting would indicate that the patient can hear only >60dB, this falls under severe impairment. WHO grading of degree of hearing loss Degree of hearing loss Hearing threshold in better ear (average of 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz) Not significant 0-25 dB Mild 26-30 dB Moderate 41-55 dB Moderately severe 56-70 dB Severe 71-91 dB Profound Above 91 dB Total Incorrect Options: Mild hearing loss (Option A): This option is incorrect as mild hearing loss is at 26 to 40dB only. Moderate hearing loss (Option B): This option is incorrect as Moderate hearing loss is at 41 to 60 dB. Profound hearing loss (Option D): This option is incorrect as Profound hearing loss is above 80 dB. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 25

questions.question: Mark the correct statement/ statements regarding Inner and Outer hair cells? I. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses. II. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells. III. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of Tectorial membrane. IV. · Outer and inner hair cells present in the ratio of 3:1.

options.A: I, II and IV are correct
options.B: I, II and III are correct

questions.explanation: correct as type 1 hair cells(inner hair cells) are single and are afferent and transmit excitatory impulses. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells. It is a correct statement as Type 2 also known as outer hair cells are multiple and efferent. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the Tectorial membrane.- It is incorrect as there is no such rule about the movement of tectorial plates. Outer and inner hair cells present in the ratio of 3:1. - It is correct as outer hair cells are around 12000 and inner hair cells are about 3500. Incorrect Options: I, II, and III (Option B): This is incorrect as the 3rd statement is false. All are correct (Option B): It is incorrect as the 3rd statement is false. II, IV (Option D): It is incorrect as the 1st statement is also correct. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 3

questions.question: During the examination of a female patient with hearing loss, it was observed that she had a negative Rinne test result at frequencies of 256 Hz and 512 Hz, but a positive Rinne test result at 1024 Hz. What would be the anticipated gap between air conduction and bone conduction in this case?
questions.explanation: 256 Hz and 512 Hz : → Bone conduction (BC) > Air conduction (AC) → Suggests conductive hearing loss at lower frequencies. Rinne positive at 1024 Hz : → AC > BC , which may occur if: The conductive loss is mild at high frequencies, or The air-bone gap is narrower at higher frequencies . The negative Rinne at low frequencies indicates a significant air-bone gap ( ≥ 15 dB). The positive Rinne at 1024 Hz suggests the gap is less than 15 dB or resolved. Since Rinne becomes positive when the air-bone gap is less than ~15 dB , and is negative when the gap is more than ~15–20 dB , this pattern suggests: An air-bone gap between 15–30 dB at lower frequencies. Incorrect Options: Options A, C and D are incorrect as explained above. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, Throat, 8th Edition, Page no: 76

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman came with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, it is found that the patient has conductive hearing loss and the Rinne test results are negative. Additionally, a reddish mass is observed located behind the tympanic membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Glomus tumour Explanation: The symptoms of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus with a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane are consistent with glomus tumor. The negative Rinne test indicates conductive hearing loss is also common in patients with glomus tumours. Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma) Definition Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma. Tumour type Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear) Origin Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies . Prevalence Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females Types Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus). Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein). Spread Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube) Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy) Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal). Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy). Clinical manifestations Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss) Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure. Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp) Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear. Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release) Histopathology No capsule (locally invasive) HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids. Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery. Otoscopy Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum). “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare). Diagnosis CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign. MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper " appearance. Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor. Acute otitis media (Option A): is less likely as it typically presents with ear pain, fever, and fluid or pus in the middle ear. Chronic otitis media (Option B): may present with conductive hearing loss but is less likely to have a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane. Serous otitis media (Option D): may cause conductive hearing loss, but it is typically not associated with pulsatile tinnitus and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with CSF otorrhea?

options.B: Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane
options.D: Fracture of the roof of the nose

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Battle sign Explanation: CSF otorrhea is a condition where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks out of the skull through the ear. Battle sign is a physical finding that occurs with CSF leakage into the mastoid air cells from a fracture of the temporal bone. Battle sign is bruising over the mastoid process, which is generally brought on by head trauma. CSF Rhinorrhea Leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) into the nose. Can present as clear fluid or mixed with blood , especially in acute head injuries. Common Sites of CSF Rhinorrhea Anterior cranial fossa Middle cranial fossa Temporal bone fracture Cribriform plate(most common) Roof of ethmoid air cells Frontal sinus Sphenoid sinus(following trauma) CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea) Aetiology Trauma(Most common): Accidental or surgical (e.g., sinus surgery, nasal polypectomy, skull base surgery). Inflammations: Mucocoeles, fungal infections, osteomyelitis, sinus polyposis. Neoplasms: Benign and malignant tumours invading the skull base. Congenital: Meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, gliomas with skull base defects. Idiopathic: Spontaneous leaks with no known cause. Investigations for CSF Rhinorrhea Handkerchief test (Halo sign): Simple bedside test; CSF forms clear halo around blood spot. Beta-2 transferrin: Gold standard biochemical test; highly specific for CSF. High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Identifies bony defects in skull base. CT Cisternography: Contrast-enhanced; precise localization of active CSF leaks. MRI Cisternography: Non-invasive; useful for identifying meningoceles/encephaloceles. Fluorescein Test: Intrathecal dye injection; helps in intraoperative leak localization. Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane, Penetrating injury to the eye, and Fracture of the roof of the nose (Options B, C, and D): are not typically associated with CSF otorrhea.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hemorrhagic Myringitis bullosa Explanation: Hemorrhagic bullae (fluid-filled blisters with blood) on the tympanic membrane (as seen in the otoscopy image) are characteristic of Myringitis bullosa . The cause is a viral or bacterial infection. Symptoms commonly include sudden otalgia (ear pain), reduced hearing , and sometimes bloody otorrhea if the blisters rupture. Otitis Externa Haemorrhagica/Bullous Myringitis/Myringitis Bullosa Cause: Most common: Streptococcus pneumoniae Others: Influenza virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae Clinical Features: Severe otalgia (ear pain) Ear discharge Hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane (TM) and deep external auditory meatus Management: Systemic antibiotics Antibiotic ear drops Serous otitis media (Option B): is a condition where fluid accumulates in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can cause mild to moderate hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Acute otitis media (Option C): is an infection of the middle ear that causes ear pain, fever, and sometimes discharge from the ear. Myringitis granulosa (Option D): is a condition where there are multiple small nodules or granulations on the tympanic membrane, causing hearing loss and pain. It is a rare condition and is often associated with other ear disorders, such as chronic otitis media.

questions.question: Which diagnosis is most likely for a patient experiencing painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane, along with facial nerve palsy? Furthermore, which specific site is affected in this case?

options.A: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion
options.B: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion Explanation: Ramsay Hunt syndrome (RHS) is caused by the reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the geniculate ganglion, a sensory ganglion of the facial nerve located in the temporal bone. It commonly presents with painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane, as well as ipsilateral facial nerve palsy. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome ( Herpes Zoster Oticus): Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with facial nerve palsy, a painful vesicular rash around the external auditory canal and pinna. There may be anaesthesia of face, giddiness and hearing impairment due to involvement of V th and VIII th nerve. Treatment: Medical management Steroids: Prednisolone is the drug of choice (1 mg/kg/day). Steroids can be combined with Acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus. Dosage: If reported within 1 week, administer for 5 days and taper off by the 10th day. If paralysis persists, continue the same dose for 10 more days. Surgical Treatment Nerve Decompression: Relieves pressure on nerve fibers, improving microcirculation. Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion (Option A): Incorrect because the basal ganglia are part of the central nervous system and unrelated to the facial nerve or VZV reactivation. Melkersson syndrome and trigeminal ganglion (Option C): Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome involves recurrent facial swelling, facial palsy, and fissured tongue. It is not associated with vesicles or VZV infection. Melkersson syndrome and otic ganglion (Option D): Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome does not involve the otic ganglion, and otic ganglion lesions do not cause these symptoms.

questions.question: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Linear acceleration and deceleration Explanation: The utricle and saccule are parts of the vestibular system in the inner ear. The sensory epithelium of the utricle and sacula is called the macula which is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration They contain specialized sensory hair cells that respond to movement and acceleration of the head in different directions, sending signals to the brain to help maintain balance and spatial orientation. Parts of the Inner Ear The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth. Bony Labyrinth A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts: Vestibule: Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals. Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth). Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration. Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation. Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear. Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations. Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals. Membranous Labyrinth A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes: Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease. Hearing high-frequency sounds (Option A): This is the function of the cochlea, which is another part of the inner ear responsible for hearing. Angular acceleration (Option C): This is detected by the semicircular canals, which are also part of the vestibular system but are responsible for detecting rotational movements of the head. Hearing low-frequency sounds (Option D): This is the function of the cochlea.

questions.question: What is the preferred treatment for a primipara who is experiencing hearing impairment that has worsened during her pregnancy? The Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, while the Weber's test shows lateralization to the right side. The otoscopy reveals normal tympanic membranes, and audiometry indicates a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz.
questions.explanation: Bone conduction is preferable to air conduction, which is indicative of conductive hearing loss, according to the negative results of the Rinne test in both ears. Otosclerosis, a disorder in which there is abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that interferes with sound transmission, is the most likely reason for conductive hearing loss in a pregnant woman. The preferred method of treatment for otosclerosis is stapedotomy. A small hole is drilled or laser-cut into the footplate during stapedotomy to allow for the insertion of a prosthesis through the footplate. Therefore, the correct treatment for the condition is stapedotomy. Incorrect choices: Option a: Sodium fluoride: While sodium fluoride may be used in some circumstances to slow the development of otosclerosis, it is not a guaranteed cure. In circumstances when otosclerosis has been diagnosed but the patient has not yet had hearing loss, sodium fluoride may be used to treat mild cases of the condition. Option b: Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical treatment used to reconstruct the middle ear or repair a damaged eardrum. It might be necessary if there has been trauma or infection that has damaged the eardrum or middle ear. Option c: Stapedectomy: Stapedectomy is a procedure by which the entire stapes footplate is removed which can cause more postoperative complications, thus stapedectomy is not preferred over stapedotomy.

questions.question: Match the following Wullstein's Classification Procedure/other name A. Type II the incus 3. Cavum minor 4. Columella tympanoplasty
questions.explanation: Classification): Type Description Type I Myringoplasty: Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane using a graft. Type II Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus with an eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane. Type III Graft placed directly on stapes head in absence of malleus and incus (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty). Type IV Graft placed between oval and round windows, exposing stapes footplate (cavum minor), allowing sound to act directly on footplate. Type V Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional. Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 34, 35

questions.question: Which of the following tests can be used if the otoacoustic emission test is absent during screening? Pure tone audiometry. Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry
questions.explanation: absent because it can assess middle ear function and identify conductive hearing loss, which may be responsible for the absence of OAES. Speech audiometry assesses how well a person can hear and understand speech, which is essential for communication in everyday life. Unlike pure tone audiometry, which tests hearing sensitivity to pure tones, speech audiometry uses speech as the test stimulus. Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) , a test in which emissions are generated by outer hair cells and are used to evaluate hearing in individuals with cognitive impairments. OAEs are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal. Pathway: The absence of OAE indicates damage in the outer hair cell (conditions like lesions of the cochlea, middle ear disorders, etc.). Types: Spontaneous OAEs involve emissions without any external stimulation (sound). They may be absent in 50% of the individuals. Evoked OAEs require an external stimulus. Transient evoked OAEs (TEOAEs) : Evoked by clicks (mixture of various frequencies). Distortion product OAEs: Two tones (specific frequencies) are simultaneously presented to the cochlea to produce distortion products. Uses of OAE: They are used as a screening test for neonates, uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals. Differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss. Helpful in early detection of noise-induced hearing loss. Tympanometry/Inflation-deflation test: (Statement b) Principle: When a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. Normal: The ability of the tube to equilibrate positive and negative pressures to the ambient pressure. The most reliable test for eustachian tube dysfunction is tympanometry. Tests to differentiate between cochlear and retro cochlear pathology: Normal Cochlear pathology Retrocochlear pathology Speech discrimination Score (Statement d) 90-100% Below 90% Very poor Recruitment Absent Present Absent SISI score 0-15% >70% 0-20% Threshold tone decay Test 0-15 dB <25 dB >25 dB Stapedial reflex Present Present Absent Stapedial reflex decay Normal Normal Abnormal BERA Normal interval between wave I and V Normal interval between wave I and V Wave V delayed or absent Rollover phenomenon Absent primarily but seen in old age Absent Present

questions.question: A 6 year old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high arched palate, and impaired hearing. His tympanogram is given below. What would be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.explanation: shows a flat tracing, indicating reduced or absent movement of the tympanic membrane. This is a classic finding in middle ear effusion, where fluid fills the middle ear space and restricts the membrane's movement. The most likely underlying problem is adenoid hypertrophy obstructing the Eustachian tube leading to recurrent infections, effusion, and hearing impairment. Adenoidectomy and grommet insertion are the most appropriate management. Tympanometry : Measures the compliance (stiffness) of the tympano-ossicular system by detecting the reflected sound energy. Can also test Eustachian tube function by pressure changes and swallowing. Different tympanogram types indicate middle ear pathologies: Tympanogram Type Characteristics Indication Type A Normal peak Normal middle ear function Type As Shallow peak Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis) Type Ad Deep peak Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane Type B Flat, no peak Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane Type C Peak at negative pressure Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure Serous Otitis Media (Glue Ear) Serous Otitis Media (SOM) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of non-purulent, often thick effusion in the middle ear, commonly affecting school-aged children. Pathogenesis: The Eustachian tube fails to aerate and drain fluid from the middle ear. Increased Secretory Activity of Middle Ear Mucosa. Aetiology: Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube Allergy Unresolved otitis media Viral infections Adenoid hyperplasia . Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis . Chronic tonsillitis : Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function. Nasopharyngeal tumours : Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media. Palatal defects : e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis. Down's syndrome . Seasonal or perennial

questions.question: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: 1. Cochlear nucleus 2. Spiral ganglion 3. Superior olivary nucleus 4. Inferior colliculus 5. Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation: with the spiral ganglion (which contains cell bodies of auditory nerve fibers). In response to sound, the cochlear hair cells generate impulses that are transmitted along these auditory fibers. 1-Cochlear nucleus: These fibers enter the brainstem and synapse with the cochlear nucleus. 3-Superior olivary nucleus: Some fibers cross to the opposite side and enter the superior olivary complex. 4-Inferior colliculus: The fibers ascend and enter the inferior colliculus (midbrain). 5- Medial geniculate body: Signals are relayed to the medial geniculate body (thalamus). Fibers then relay to the auditory cortex (Brodmann's area 41) (superior temporal gyrus). Auditory pathway: Cochlea Cochlear Nerve Cochlear Nucleus (in the brainstem) Superior Olivary Complex Lateral Lemniscus Inferior Colliculus (in the midbrain) Medial Geniculate Nucleus (in the thalamus) Primary Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals are sent to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (Heschl’s gyrus) , where sound perception, including the identification of pitch, rhythm and speech occurs.

questions.question: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image according to the Sade classification?
questions.explanation: retraction. The tympanic membrane gets retracted deep enough to come in contact with the incus and stapes . Grade 1 : Slight retraction of the pars tensa. Grade 2 : Retraction onto the incus. (Option B) Grade 3 : Retraction onto the promontory, but not adherent. Grade 4 : Adhesion onto the promontory.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of slowly progressive difficulty hearing in the right ear. She also has pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit was heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope was performed. Her Rinne test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Glomus tumor Explanation: A glomus tumor is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. Glomus tumors, also known as glomus jugulare tumors, are vascular lesions that occur in the middle ear, often behind the tympanic membrane. The patient's presentation of pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit over the mastoid are all characteristic signs of a glomus tumor. These tumors are rich in blood vessels and can cause conductive hearing loss due to their location in the middle ear, which may explain the negative Rinne test (indicative of conductive hearing loss). Type Glomus Tympanicum Glomus Jugulare Location Tumours arise from the promontory of the middle ear. Tumours originate from the dome of the jugular bulb and can extend into the middle ear and surrounding structures. Manifestations Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane. Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and may involve multiple cranial nerves (IX, X, XI) Otoscopy findings Reddish, pulsatile mass behind the tympanic membrane. This may lead to conductive hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often pulsatile. It is associated with neurological symptoms due to cranial nerve involvement, including glossopharyngeal nerve involvement. Investigations of Glomus Tumour CT scan CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the investigation of choice to distinguish between glomus tympanicum and glomus jugulare tumours and to differentiate them from an aberrant carotid artery, a high jugular bulb, or a dehiscent jugular bulb. Phelps sign: On the normal side, the carotico-jugular spine (a dense bone structure between the jugular and mastoid) is intact. On the affected side, erosion of the carotico-jugular spine is observed. MRI scan It demonstrates the extent of the tumour within the soft tissue. Salt and pepper sign: Microhemorrhages within the tumour are visualized as white and gray dots on MRI, resulting in a "salt-and-pepper" appearance. Angiography It is essential when CT indicates involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension. It also aids in identifying additional glomus tumors, locating feeding vessels, and guiding embolization. Brain Perfusion and Flow Studies These are essential if the tumor compresses the internal carotid artery. They assess brain perfusion, contralateral carotid artery function, and may involve xenon blood flow and isotope studies to gauge stroke risk and the need for artery replacement. Biopsy Histopathological studies show the Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids. Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery. Incorrect Options: CSOM (Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media) (Option A) : CSOM is a chronic ear infection, often associated with purulent drainage and ear

questions.question: What are the objective tests used to assess hearing ability? A. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) B. OAE (Otoacoustic emission) C. PTA (Pure tone audiometry) D. Tympanometry
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) A, B, C and D Explanation: All of the tests listed (A, B, C, and D) are objective methods used to assess hearing ability: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) (Option A) : BERA is an electrophysiological test that measures the brainstem's response to sound stimuli. It is useful for assessing auditory pathways and diagnosing hearing impairment, especially in infants and individuals unable to cooperate with traditional hearing tests. OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions) (Option B) : OAE tests measure sound waves produced by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to auditory stimuli. The presence of these emissions suggests normal cochlear function, particularly the outer hair cells of the cochlea. It is widely used in newborn hearing screening and assessing cochlear health. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) (Option C) : PTA is a standard test for assessing hearing sensitivity by presenting pure tones at different frequencies and intensities. The results provide a threshold of hearing and help in diagnosing the type and degree of hearing loss.
